response_metadata.response_text:
{
  "overview": "This Act appropriates funds for the continued implementation of the kauhale initiative. [CHUNK_15] It also creates the supportive housing special fund to assist the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation to facilitate the development of mixed-income rental housing projects for special needs individuals or families. [CHUNK_15] Additionally, the Act creates a kauhale initiative special fund to assist the statewide office of homelessness and housing solutions to implement the kauhale initiative. [CHUNK_16]",
  "appropriations": "The bill appropriates out of general revenues $50,000,000 (HB431_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and the same sum for fiscal year 2026-2027 for the continued operation of the kauhale initiative. [CHUNK_17, NUMBER_5] It also appropriates $12,000,000 (HB431_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and the same sum for fiscal year 2026-2027 to be deposited into the supportive housing special fund. [CHUNK_38, CHUNK_39, NUMBER_6, NUMBER_7] From the supportive housing special fund, $12,000,000 (HB431_.HTM.txt) is appropriated for each fiscal year 2025-2026 and 2026-2027 for projects, with $189,750 (HB431_.HTM.txt) of that amount for one temporary full-time equivalent position. [CHUNK_40, CHUNK_41, NUMBER_7, NUMBER_8]",
  "assumptions_and_methodology": "The document does not specify the methodology used to determine the appropriation amounts. [CHUNK_52] The appropriations are intended for the continued implementation and operation of the kauhale initiative, building on previous programs like the ohana zones pilot program. [CHUNK_3, CHUNK_15] The purpose of the funding is to address Hawaii's high homelessness rate by developing long-term solutions and creating affordable housing. [CHUNK_1, CHUNK_13, CHUNK_14]",
  "agency_impact": "The Hawaii housing finance and development corporation will administer the supportive housing special fund and establish one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) housing finance specialist I position. [CHUNK_25, CHUNK_26] The sums appropriated for the kauhale initiative shall be expended by the office of the governor, which may transfer funds to other executive branch departments or agencies, including the statewide office on homelessness and housing solutions. [CHUNK_19, CHUNK_20] The statewide office on homelessness and housing solutions will administer the kauhale initiative special fund. [CHUNK_46]",
  "economic_impact": "The bill is designed to address individuals with special housing needs, including those with addiction, transitioning from incarceration, youth aging out of foster care, and other vulnerable populations. [CHUNK_7] The kauhale initiative aims to create deeply affordable spaces for housing and healing the houseless. [CHUNK_8] Creating a new financing tool for supportive housing will enable the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation to facilitate the development of supportive housing units in stand-alone projects or integrated in mixed-income rental housing projects. [CHUNK_24]",
  "policy_impact": "This Act amends Chapter 201H, Hawaii Revised Statutes, by establishing a supportive housing special fund. [CHUNK_27] It also amends Chapter 346, Hawaii Revised Statutes, by establishing a kauhale initiative special fund. [CHUNK_46] The bill also establishes one temporary full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) housing finance specialist I position within the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation. [CHUNK_41]",
  "revenue_sources": "Appropriations are made from the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [CHUNK_17, CHUNK_38] The supportive housing special fund may include sums appropriated by the legislature, private contributions, proceeds from repayment of loans, interest, fees, other returns, and moneys from other sources. [CHUNK_30, CHUNK_31] The kauhale initiative special fund may also include sums appropriated by the legislature, program revenues, private contributions, interest, and moneys from other sources. [CHUNK_47]",
  "six_year_fiscal_implications": "The bill provides appropriations for a two-year period, fiscal years 2025-2026 and 2026-2027. [CHUNK_17] It appropriates $50,000,000 (HB431_.HTM.txt) from general revenues for each of the two fiscal years for the continued operation of the kauhale initiative. [CHUNK_17, NUMBER_5] These sums shall not lapse at the end of the fiscal biennium. [CHUNK_21] For the supportive housing special fund, the bill appropriates $12,000,000 (HB431_.HTM.txt) from general revenues for deposit in FY 2025-2026 and the same sum in FY 2026-2027. [CHUNK_38, CHUNK_39, NUMBER_6, NUMBER_7] From this special fund, $12,000,000 (HB431_.HTM.txt) is appropriated for expenditure in each of those two fiscal years. [CHUNK_40, NUMBER_7] This includes $189,750 (HB431_.HTM.txt) each year for one temporary full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) housing finance specialist I position. [CHUNK_41, NUMBER_8] The document does not provide a fiscal outlook beyond these two years. [CHUNK_52]",
  "operating_revenue_impact": "The Hawaii housing finance and development corporation may establish, revise, charge, and collect a reasonable service fee in connection with its financing, services, and approvals. [CHUNK_35] These fees shall be deposited into the supportive housing special fund. [CHUNK_36] The kauhale initiative special fund may include program revenues as a source of funds. [CHUNK_47]",
  "capital_expenditure_impact": "Moneys in the supportive housing special fund may be used to make loans to finance the development, pre-development, construction, acquisition, preservation, or substantial rehabilitation of supportive housing projects. [CHUNK_29] Act 128, Session Laws of Hawaii 2019, previously appropriated $2,000,000 (HB431_.HTM.txt) for the construction of modular temporary units and renovation of existing structures. [CHUNK_4, NUMBER_1] No specific capital expenditures are detailed for the current appropriations. [CHUNK_52]",
  "fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "The bill does not specify fiscal implications beyond the two-year appropriation period. [CHUNK_52] However, the establishment of the supportive housing special fund and the kauhale initiative special fund suggests an ongoing need for funding to support these initiatives. [CHUNK_28, CHUNK_46] These funds are designed to receive future appropriations, private contributions, and other moneys to continue their work. [CHUNK_30, CHUNK_47]",
  "updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "No previous fiscal note was provided in the source documents. [CHUNK_52]",
  "fte_positions": "The bill establishes one temporary full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) housing finance specialist I within the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation. [CHUNK_41] This position is intended to help with the administration of the supportive housing special fund. [CHUNK_26] The appropriation for this position is $189,750 (HB431_.HTM.txt) for each of fiscal years 2025-2026 and 2026-2027 out of the supportive housing special fund. [CHUNK_41, NUMBER_8]",
  "appropriations_changes": "No previous version of the bill was provided to identify changes in appropriations. [CHUNK_52]",
  "funding_sources_changes": "No previous version of the bill was provided to identify changes in funding sources. [CHUNK_52]",
  "department_impact": "The sums appropriated for the kauhale initiative are to be expended by the office of the governor. [CHUNK_19] The governor may transfer appropriations to other executive branch departments, including the statewide office on homelessness and housing solutions. [CHUNK_20] The sum appropriated from the supportive housing special fund is to be expended by the Hawaii Housing finance and development corporation. [CHUNK_42]",
  "reports_required": "The Hawaii housing finance and development corporation shall submit a report to the legislature no later than twenty days prior to the convening of each regular session describing the projects funded using moneys from the supportive housing special fund. [CHUNK_36] The statewide office on homelessness and housing solutions shall submit a report to the legislature no later than twenty days prior to the convening of each regular session describing the deposits to and uses of moneys from the kauhale initiative special fund. [CHUNK_48]",
  "pilot_program": "This bill does not establish a new pilot program. [CHUNK_52] It continues and expands initiatives that evolved from previous pilot programs, such as the ohana zones pilot program and a 2023 supportive housing pilot program. [CHUNK_3, CHUNK_6] The bill establishes permanent special funds to support the ongoing kauhale initiative and the development of supportive housing. [CHUNK_16, CHUNK_25]",
  "sunset_date": "The provided text of the bill does not include a sunset date. [CHUNK_52]",
  "effective_date": "This Act shall take effect on June 29, 2025. [CHUNK_50] However, sections 2, 5, and 6, which contain the appropriations, shall take effect on July 1, 2025. [CHUNK_50]"
}

chunk_details.chunk_text: HB431 HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES H.B. NO. 431 THIRTY-THIRD LEGISLATURE, 2025 STATE OF HAWAII A BILL FOR AN ACT relating to housing . BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF HAWAII: PART I SECTION 1. The legislature finds that Hawaii has the highest homelessness rate per capita in

that Hawaii has the highest homelessness rate per capita in the nation. The 2024 Point In Time Count showed a total of 6,389 people experiencing homelessness in the State. The majority of the homeless are on Oahu with 4,494, followed by Hawaii with seven hundred eighteen, Maui with six hundred

by Hawaii with seven hundred eighteen, Maui with six hundred fifty-four, and Kauai with five hundred twenty-three homeless individuals. Between 2023 and 2024, there was a twelve per cent increase in the number of people experiencing homelessness on Oahu. Sixty-two per cent of Oahu's homeless were unsheltered, and thirty-eight per

per cent of Oahu's homeless were unsheltered, and thirty-eight per cent were sheltered. The legislature under Act 209, Session Laws of Hawaii 2018, established the ohana zones pilot program, which initially appropriated $30,000,000 to fund nonprofit and county government programs aimed to reduce homelessness. Act 128, Session Laws of Hawaii

aimed to reduce homelessness. Act 128, Session Laws of Hawaii 2019, expanded the use of ohana zone funds to include private lands and appropriated $2,000,000 for the construction of modular temporary units, renovation of existing structures on public lands, or creation of infrastructure to make land suitable for temporary housing.

creation of infrastructure to make land suitable for temporary housing. The ohana zones pilot program was extended from 2021 to 2023. The legislature finds that in addition to the six mandated housing sites in the ohana zones pilot program, fourteen additional programs were established. Act 235, Session Laws of Hawaii

additional programs were established. Act 235, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, further extended the ohana zones pilot program through June 30, 2026, and provided an additional $15,000,000 to fund services. In 2023, the legislature also set aside $5,000,000 to fund a supportive housing pilot program, designed to address individuals with

a supportive housing pilot program, designed to address individuals with special housing needs, including individuals with alcohol or drug addiction, individuals transitioning from incarceration, youth aging out of foster care, domestic violence survivors, veterans, individuals with intellectual, developmental, physical disabilities, or mental illness, frail elderly, and chronically homeless individuals. In

or mental illness, frail elderly, and chronically homeless individuals. In 2023, the legislature also set aside $25,000,000 to fund the kauhale initiative to create deeply affordable spaces for housing and healing the houseless. At that time, kauhale was defined as "communal living spaces, with modest housing units for individual households

"communal living spaces, with modest housing units for individual households and shared space for cooking, eating, recreation, growing food, and engaging in group activities". As proposed, kauhale was envisioned as "prefabricated homes, or other modest, low-cost housing unit," but "could also be created in an existing apartment, dormitory, or office

also be created in an existing apartment, dormitory, or office building, so long as there is communal space and an investment in building communal responsibility." Over time, the kauhale initiative has evolved to a range of responses for homeless individuals and families and those at risk of homelessness. Kauhale now

and families and those at risk of homelessness. Kauhale now include temporary, time limited options such as emergency shelter, medical respite, and mobile outreach and navigation, as well as long term solutions such as supportive housing and affordable housing targeting extremely low-income households. The legislature further finds that among the

extremely low-income households. The legislature further finds that among the important principles of the State's kauhale initiative is building partnerships between government and community, providing affordable spaces for housing and healing, and fostering belonging and responsibility. Every kauhale is a partnership between government and community with flexible state funding used

partnership between government and community with flexible state funding used to empower community champions to fill resource gaps where needed. The legislature also finds that to ensure there is capacity within the State to meet the needs for long-term solutions to homelessness and the risk of homelessness, it is necessary

to homelessness and the risk of homelessness, it is necessary for the State to develop the capacity of its affordable housing financing and development agency to work with developers to create additional supportive housing units. Accordingly, the purpose of this Act is to: (1) Appropriate funds for the continued implementation

Act is to: (1) Appropriate funds for the continued implementation of the kauhale initiative; (2) Create the supportive housing special fund to assist the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation to facilitate the development of mixed-income rental housing projects in which some or all the units are targeted to special

which some or all the units are targeted to special needs individuals or families who require supportive services; and (3) Create a kauhale initiative special fund to assist the statewide office of homelessness and housing solutions to implement the kauhale initiative. PART II SECTION 2. There is appropriated out of

initiative. PART II SECTION 2. There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii the sum of $50,000,000 or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2025-2026 and the same sum or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2026-2027

much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2026-2027 for the continued operation of the kauhale initiative including expenses related to the development and operation of kauhale, provision of project-based rent supplement payments, provision of support services for qualified individuals and families in kauhale, and staffing and related costs

individuals and families in kauhale, and staffing and related costs to administer the kauhale initiative . The sums appropriated shall be expended by the office of the governor for the purposes of this Act. Notwithstanding any other law to the contrary, the governor may transfer all or a portion of

contrary, the governor may transfer all or a portion of the appropriation in this part to the governor's designated executive branch departments or agencies, including the statewide office on homelessness and housing solutions for expenditures incurred to implement the program. The governor's designated executive branch departments or agencies may expend

The governor's designated executive branch departments or agencies may expend any appropriation transferred pursuant to this part for the performance of their duties under the kauhale initiative. The sums appropriated under this section shall not lapse at the end of the fiscal biennium for which the appropriation is made. PART

the fiscal biennium for which the appropriation is made. PART III SECTION 3. The legislature finds that combining affordable housing with access to services to help special needs populations, such as individuals with alcohol or drug addiction, individuals transitioning from incarceration, youth aging out of foster care, domestic violence survivors,

incarceration, youth aging out of foster care, domestic violence survivors, veterans, individuals with intellectual, developmental, physical disabilities, or mental illness, frail elderly, and chronically homeless individuals, live more stable and productive lives. The legislature further finds that the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation administers various programs to finance mixed-income

finance and development corporation administers various programs to finance mixed-income rental housing developments. Creating a new financing tool specifically for supportive housing will enable the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation to facilitate the development of supportive housing units in stand-alone projects or integrated in mixed-income rental housing projects. stand-alone projects or integrated in mixed-income rental housing projects. The purpose of this part is to: (1) Establish a supportive housing special fund to be administered by the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation; (2) Appropriate funds to support the development, operation, and maintenance of supportive housing, as well as

development, operation, and maintenance of supportive housing, as well as the provision of supportive services; and (3) Establish, within the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation, one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) housing finance specialist I position to help with the administration of the supportive housing special fund. Chapter 201H, Hawaii Revised Statutes, is amended by adding a new subpart to part III to be appropriately designated and to read as follows: " . Supportive Housing Special Fund §201H- Supportive housing special fund. (a) There is established a supportive

Supportive housing special fund. (a) There is established a supportive housing special fund to be administered by the corporation for the purpose of developing, operating, and maintaining affordable, permanent housing and the provision of supportive services for individuals or families with special needs. (b) Moneys in the fund may be

with special needs. supportive services for households residing in the supportive housing projects; and (4) For other housing services or activities as provided in rules adopted by the corporation without regard to chapter 91. finds that the statewide office on homelessness and housing solutions is responsible for working with State, county, and community agencies to develop solutions to prevent and end homelessness in the State through transitional and permanent housing and supportive or assisted services, or both. numbers_data.text: 2024, there was a twelve per cent increase in the number of people experiencing homelessness on Oahu. Sixty-two per cent of Oahu's homeless were unsheltered, and thirty-eight per cent were sheltered. The legislature under Act 209, Session Laws of Hawaii 2018, established the ohana zones pilot program, which initially appropriated $30,000,000 to fund nonprofit and county government programs aimed to reduce homelessness. Act 128, Session Laws of Hawaii 2019, expanded the use of ohana zone funds to include private lands and appropriated $2,000,000 for the construction of modular temporary units, renovation of existing structures on public lands, or creation of infrastructure

legislature under Act 209, Session Laws of Hawaii 2018, established the ohana zones pilot program, which initially appropriated $30,000,000 to fund nonprofit and county government programs aimed to reduce homelessness. Act 128, Session Laws of Hawaii 2019, expanded the use of ohana zone funds to include private lands and appropriated $2,000,000 for the construction of modular temporary units, renovation of existing structures on public lands, or creation of infrastructure to make land suitable for temporary housing. extended from 2021 to 2023. The legislature finds that in addition to the six mandated housing sites in the ohana zones pilot program, fourteen additional programs were established. overview.prompt: Using the provided legislative documents, statutes, and testimonies, write a clear summary describing the purpose, scope, and key components of the proposed measure or bill, including any pilot or permanent programs, reporting requirements, and sunset clauses. This should be around 3 sentences.
overview.description: General overview and summary of the measure

appropriations.prompt: Based on budgetary data and legislative appropriations, detail the funding allocated for the program or measure, including fiscal years, amounts, intended uses such as staffing, training, contracts, technology, etc... This should be around 3 sentences.

assumptions_and_methodology.prompt: Explain the assumptions, cost estimation methods, and data sources used to calculate the financial projections for this program or measure, referencing comparable programs or historical budgets where applicable. This should be around 3 sentences.

agency_impact.prompt: Describe the anticipated operational, administrative, and budgetary impact of the program or measure on the relevant government agency or department, including supervision, staffing, and resource allocation. This should be around 3 sentences.
agency_impact.description: Impact on government agencies and departments

economic_impact.prompt: Summarize the expected economic effects of the program or measure, such as cost savings, potential reductions in related expenditures, benefits to the community, and any relevant performance or participation statistics. This should be around 3 sentences.

policy_impact.prompt: Analyze the policy implications of the measure, including how it modifies existing laws or programs, its role within broader legislative strategies, and its potential effects on state or local governance. This should be around 3 sentences.

revenue_sources.prompt: Identify and describe the funding sources that will support the program or measure, such as general funds, grants, fees, or other revenue streams, based on the provided fiscal documents. This should be around 3 sentences.

six_year_fiscal_implications.prompt: Provide a multi-year fiscal outlook (e.g., six years) for the program or measure, projecting costs, staffing changes, recurring expenses, and assumptions about program expansion or permanence using available budget and workload data. This should be around 10 sentences.

operating_revenue_impact.prompt: Describe any anticipated impacts on operating revenues resulting from the program or measure, including increases, decreases, or changes in revenue streams. This should be around 3 sentences.

capital_expenditure_impact.prompt: Outline any expected capital expenditures related to the program or measure, such as investments in facilities, equipment, or technology infrastructure, based on capital budgets or agency plans. This should be around 3 sentences.

fiscal_implications_after_6_years.prompt: Summarize the ongoing fiscal obligations after the initial multi-year period for the program or measure, including annual operating costs, expected number of program sites or units, and the sustainability of funding. This should be around 3 sentences.
fiscal_implications_after_6_years.description: Long-term fiscal obligations beyond six years

updates_from_previous_fiscal_note.prompt: If you are given a previous fiscal note. Please summarize the MAIN POINTS that are different from the previous fiscal note and the new fiscal note.

fte_positions.prompt: Detail any Full Time Equivalent (FTE) positions that have been added or modified in this version of the bill, including the number of positions, their roles, and any changes from previous versions. This should be around 3 sentences.

appropriations_changes.prompt: Identify and describe any appropriations that were previously unspecified or have been modified between versions of the bill, including the amounts and purposes of the appropriations. This should be around 3 sentences.
appropriations_changes.description: Changes to appropriations between bill versions

funding_sources_changes.prompt: Specify the method of funding (MOF) for appropriations and identify any changes in funding sources between versions, such as shifts between general fund and special fund appropriations. This should be around 3 sentences.
funding_sources_changes.description: Changes to funding sources and method of funding

department_impact.prompt: Describe any changes in which department is responsible for expending appropriations, including shifts from one department to another between bill versions (e.g., from Department of Health to Judiciary). This should be around 3 sentences.
department_impact.description: Changes in department responsibility for appropriations

reports_required.prompt: Identify any reports that agencies are required to submit to the legislature, including new reporting requirements or modifications to existing ones. This should be around 3 sentences.

pilot_program.prompt: If the bill creates a pilot program, describe the length of the pilot program and whether it was initially intended to be a pilot program or a permanent program. This should be around 3 sentences.

sunset_date.prompt: Identify the sunset date for the bill or program, including any modifications to the sunset date between versions. This should be around 2 sentences.

effective_date.prompt: Identify the effective date of the bill, noting if there was a defective effective date in a previous version and what the corrected effective date is. This should be around 2 sentences.

HB431.chunk_text: HB431 HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES H.B. NO. 431 THIRTY-THIRD LEGISLATURE, 2025 STATE OF HAWAII A BILL FOR AN ACT relating to housing . BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF HAWAII: PART I SECTION 1. The legislature finds that Hawaii has the highest homelessness rate per capita in

that Hawaii has the highest homelessness rate per capita in the nation. The 2024 Point In Time Count showed a total of 6,389 people experiencing homelessness in the State. The majority of the homeless are on Oahu with 4,494, followed by Hawaii with seven hundred eighteen, Maui with six hundred

by Hawaii with seven hundred eighteen, Maui with six hundred fifty-four, and Kauai with five hundred twenty-three homeless individuals. Between 2023 and 2024, there was a twelve per cent increase in the number of people experiencing homelessness on Oahu. Sixty-two per cent of Oahu's homeless were unsheltered, and thirty-eight per

per cent of Oahu's homeless were unsheltered, and thirty-eight per cent were sheltered. The legislature under Act 209, Session Laws of Hawaii 2018, established the ohana zones pilot program, which initially appropriated $30,000,000 to fund nonprofit and county government programs aimed to reduce homelessness. Act 128, Session Laws of Hawaii

aimed to reduce homelessness. Act 128, Session Laws of Hawaii 2019, expanded the use of ohana zone funds to include private lands and appropriated $2,000,000 for the construction of modular temporary units, renovation of existing structures on public lands, or creation of infrastructure to make land suitable for temporary housing.

creation of infrastructure to make land suitable for temporary housing. The ohana zones pilot program was extended from 2021 to 2023. The legislature finds that in addition to the six mandated housing sites in the ohana zones pilot program, fourteen additional programs were established. Act 235, Session Laws of Hawaii

additional programs were established. Act 235, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, further extended the ohana zones pilot program through June 30, 2026, and provided an additional $15,000,000 to fund services. In 2023, the legislature also set aside $5,000,000 to fund a supportive housing pilot program, designed to address individuals with

a supportive housing pilot program, designed to address individuals with special housing needs, including individuals with alcohol or drug addiction, individuals transitioning from incarceration, youth aging out of foster care, domestic violence survivors, veterans, individuals with intellectual, developmental, physical disabilities, or mental illness, frail elderly, and chronically homeless individuals. In

or mental illness, frail elderly, and chronically homeless individuals. In 2023, the legislature also set aside $25,000,000 to fund the kauhale initiative to create deeply affordable spaces for housing and healing the houseless. At that time, kauhale was defined as "communal living spaces, with modest housing units for individual households

"communal living spaces, with modest housing units for individual households and shared space for cooking, eating, recreation, growing food, and engaging in group activities". As proposed, kauhale was envisioned as "prefabricated homes, or other modest, low-cost housing unit," but "could also be created in an existing apartment, dormitory, or office

also be created in an existing apartment, dormitory, or office building, so long as there is communal space and an investment in building communal responsibility." Over time, the kauhale initiative has evolved to a range of responses for homeless individuals and families and those at risk of homelessness. Kauhale now

and families and those at risk of homelessness. Kauhale now include temporary, time limited options such as emergency shelter, medical respite, and mobile outreach and navigation, as well as long term solutions such as supportive housing and affordable housing targeting extremely low-income households. The legislature further finds that among the

extremely low-income households. The legislature further finds that among the important principles of the State's kauhale initiative is building partnerships between government and community, providing affordable spaces for housing and healing, and fostering belonging and responsibility. Every kauhale is a partnership between government and community with flexible state funding used

partnership between government and community with flexible state funding used to empower community champions to fill resource gaps where needed. The legislature also finds that to ensure there is capacity within the State to meet the needs for long-term solutions to homelessness and the risk of homelessness, it is necessary

to homelessness and the risk of homelessness, it is necessary for the State to develop the capacity of its affordable housing financing and development agency to work with developers to create additional supportive housing units. Accordingly, the purpose of this Act is to: (1) Appropriate funds for the continued implementation

Act is to: (1) Appropriate funds for the continued implementation of the kauhale initiative; (2) Create the supportive housing special fund to assist the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation to facilitate the development of mixed-income rental housing projects in which some or all the units are targeted to special

which some or all the units are targeted to special needs individuals or families who require supportive services; and (3) Create a kauhale initiative special fund to assist the statewide office of homelessness and housing solutions to implement the kauhale initiative. PART II SECTION 2. There is appropriated out of

initiative. PART II SECTION 2. There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii the sum of $50,000,000 or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2025-2026 and the same sum or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2026-2027

much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2026-2027 for the continued operation of the kauhale initiative including expenses related to the development and operation of kauhale, provision of project-based rent supplement payments, provision of support services for qualified individuals and families in kauhale, and staffing and related costs

individuals and families in kauhale, and staffing and related costs to administer the kauhale initiative . The sums appropriated shall be expended by the office of the governor for the purposes of this Act. Notwithstanding any other law to the contrary, the governor may transfer all or a portion of

contrary, the governor may transfer all or a portion of the appropriation in this part to the governor's designated executive branch departments or agencies, including the statewide office on homelessness and housing solutions for expenditures incurred to implement the program. The governor's designated executive branch departments or agencies may expend

The governor's designated executive branch departments or agencies may expend any appropriation transferred pursuant to this part for the performance of their duties under the kauhale initiative. The sums appropriated under this section shall not lapse at the end of the fiscal biennium for which the appropriation is made. PART

the fiscal biennium for which the appropriation is made. PART III SECTION 3. The legislature finds that combining affordable housing with access to services to help special needs populations, such as individuals with alcohol or drug addiction, individuals transitioning from incarceration, youth aging out of foster care, domestic violence survivors,

incarceration, youth aging out of foster care, domestic violence survivors, veterans, individuals with intellectual, developmental, physical disabilities, or mental illness, frail elderly, and chronically homeless individuals, live more stable and productive lives. The legislature further finds that the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation administers various programs to finance mixed-income

finance and development corporation administers various programs to finance mixed-income rental housing developments. Creating a new financing tool specifically for supportive housing will enable the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation to facilitate the development of supportive housing units in stand-alone projects or integrated in mixed-income rental housing projects. stand-alone projects or integrated in mixed-income rental housing projects. The purpose of this part is to: (1) Establish a supportive housing special fund to be administered by the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation; (2) Appropriate funds to support the development, operation, and maintenance of supportive housing, as well as

development, operation, and maintenance of supportive housing, as well as the provision of supportive services; and (3) Establish, within the Hawaii housing finance and development corporation, one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) housing finance specialist I position to help with the administration of the supportive housing special fund. Supportive housing special fund. with special needs. finds that the statewide office on homelessness and housing solutions is responsible for working with State, county, and community agencies to develop solutions to prevent and end homelessness in the State through transitional and permanent housing and supportive or assisted services, or both. services, or both.
